importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the most recent update on the ongoing flooding crisis in Mexico, reflecting the current timeline of the disaster and emergency response efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding events occurred during a specific time period, highlighting the duration and recurrence of extreme weather conditions that overwhelmed local infrastructure.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding affecting five states.
Veracruz reported 29 deaths, Hidalgo 21, Puebla 13, and Queretaro 1.
65 people remain missing, including 43 in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and 4 in Puebla.
Over 100,000 houses have been affected, with some properties near rivers essentially destroyed.
The flooding was caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla) at 280mm and 286mm respectively.
Thousands of military troops from the Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to deliver food, water, and emergency aid.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of the electricity supply, with about 263,000 users losing power.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported the death and missing totals during President Claudia Sheinbaum’s daily briefing.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no clear meteorological warnings that could have predicted the extreme rainfall magnitude.
Governors of the affected states are coordinating regional support and emergency responses.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused catastrophic flooding across five Mexican states, resulting in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The worst-hit areas were Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths), with extreme rainfall recorded in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso. Thousands of military personnel from the Army, Air Force, and National Guard were deployed to deliver food, clean water, and emergency aid, while repair workers restored over 80% of electricity services. Despite efforts, the lack of early meteorological warnings raised concerns about Mexico’s disaster preparedness systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
